snippet: New York first started building housing projects on the waterfront because that’s where its poorest citizens happened to live, and continued because that’s where space was most readily available.
abstract: Jonathan Mahler essay looks at New York City's waterfront housing projects, the placement of which was a combination of accident, grand vision and political expedience under the urban planning guidance of Robert Moses; notes the catastrophic impact of Hurricane Sandy on housing projects in areas like the Rockaways can almost look like a perverse stroke of urban planning.
lead_paragraph: New York first started building housing projects on the waterfront because that’s where its poorest citizens happened to live, and continued because that’s where space was most readily available.
